subject: ECB announces EUR 750bln Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme
content:

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US CDC said total cases rose to 7087 (Prev. 4275) and death toll rose to 97 (Prev. 75). (Newswires)

Italy coronavirus cases rose to 35713 (Prev. 31506) and the death toll rose by 475 to 2978. (Newswires)

US President Trump said Defense Production Act will be signed imminently and that FEMA is activated in all regions, while VP Pence said that President Trump is to hold a videoconference with Governors and FEMA on Thursday. (Newswires) In other news, Trump administration proposed lending to air carriers from the exchange stabilization fund following the new USD 50bln congressional appropriation, according to Treasury memo. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that money is coming for those out of work due to containment measures and stated that "The onslaught of the Chinese Virus is not your fault!". Furthermore, US President Trump also said he believes China could have given notice of COVID-19 a lot earlier. (Newswires)

US Senate approved House coronavirus bill which allows free testing for coronavirus and required paid sick leave for workers impacted by coronavirus. (Newswires)

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said Republicans are close to an agreement on larger economic stimulus legislation for coronavirus. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow said the Phase 3 economic relief bill should bring USD 1.3trln worth of stimulus and that the US has enormous resources to deal with distressed industries, while he added that if it takes more than USD 1.3trln worth of stimulus, it will be done and that the government may take equity positions in companies as part of an aid package. (Newswires)

NY Governor Cuomo said that no business is allowed to have over 50% of its workforce on site; essential members are excluded. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson said we will not hesitate to bring further and faster measures where we think it is necessary, while he added the government will rule nothing out when asked about travel restrictions, while other reports suggested that PM Johnson has asked departments to draw up plans for London lockdown in which the Cabinet Office has asked for proposals on restrictions, implementation and compliance measures being called the ‘London Shielding Plan. (Newswires/The Times)

Several senior UK sources said that a London shutdown is imminent, and Government's advisory group SAGE will advise on next steps. (Daily Mirror) There were also reports that sources close to the Mayor's office expect a shutdown in the capital in the coming days (Telegraph), while other reports noted plans to heavily restrict travel in/out of London but will keep open supermarkets and pharmacies as of Friday according to CityAMs Neilan. However, No10 sources firmly suggested London will not be shut down today or tomorrow and that this particular rumour seems to have gone into total overdrive, according to Sun's Newton Dunn. (Twitter)

UK Education Secretary Williamson confirmed schools will remain shut from Friday until further notice. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

Japanese PM Abe stated that Japan will be putting together an ample economic package and will be conducting expert hearings on the package from tomorrow. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

UK Brexit Secretary Barclay said the government is working with the BoE on economic support. (Newswires)

EU is reportedly mulling a plan that could allow ECB crisis purchases through utilising rescue fund according to sources, while there were also later source reports that the ECB GC is holding an emergency call on COVID-19 response. (Newswires)

ECB's Lagarde said she sees Eurozone GDP shrinking by 5% if coronavirus lockdown continues. (FAZ)

ECB's Rehn said expanding APP or removing issuer limit on APP could be needed. (Newswires)

ESCB is intervening via the Bank of Italy to ensure orderly conditions in the market according to Bank of Italy sources, while interventions are said to be flexible in timing and markets which will continue for as long as is necessary. (Newswires)

Senior European Parliament Lawmaker has asked ESMA to assess how much of the market sell off is due to short-selling and if short-selling is significantly amplifying sell off, then ESMA should consider a pan-EU short-selling ban. (Newswires)

German Finance Ministry and Financial Regulator announced the anti-counter cyclical capital buffer is to be cut to 0.00% from 0.25% starting April 1st In which the new regulations will give German banks a capital boost of over EUR 5bln. There were also comments from German Finance Minister Scholz that they are thinking on how they can directly support some firms given the coronavirus crisis and can help in the case of big companies such as airlines and cruise companies but are not aiming to nationalise. (Newswires)

EU HICP Final (Feb) Y/Y 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.2%). (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Energy Minister directs Aramco to continue supplying crude at a rate of 12.3mln BPD over the coming months. (Newswires)

 

US

Democrat Presidential nominee hopeful Bernie Sanders’s campaign said it is speaking with supporters to assess his campaign, while the statement stated that Sanders is turning his attention towards the coronavirus response. (Newswires)

UAW union requests Detroit's three main automakers again to close their factories and the automakers (GM, F, FCAU) agreed to shut down US factories amid COVID-19 after UAW request. (Newswires)

NYSE is to move temporarily to fully electronic trading with equities and options trading floors to temporarily close from Monday 23rd March. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Policymaker pledges to pour stimulus into the economy may partly reassure, but has not engineered a revival in confidence. Asian equities could not rise despite the 6% rally on Wall Street on Tuesday, while US futures went limit down in overnight trade. US stocks found some support shortly after the open, although selling pressures continued later in the session, hitting the 7% limit down. Albeit fiscal measures seem poised to help where possible, the world increasingly begins to adjust to a lockdown, with growing expectations, and official suggestions, of hubs such as NYC and London on the cusp of such – measures that will undoubtedly cause severe near-term economic consequences and cause large downgrades to corporate stability. Another extremely volatile day for equities with the VIX making new highs above 85. Airlines saw heavy losses once again as the operators continue to reduce capacity and take cost-cutting measures. Some reports suggest airlines are looking to quickly cut workforces through an early retirement package or unpaid leave for up to one year with medical benefits in a move to reduce costs.  Delta Airlines (DAL), one of the worst-hit today, falling over 30% as it expects revenue to fall USD 2bln in March while cutting its system-wide capacity by 70% and reducing pay to its officers and directors by 50% and 25%, respectively. Boeing (BA) was also heavily weighed on after its appeal for USD 60bln in government aid, which includes access to public and private liquidity and loan guarantees for the aerospace manufacturing industry. SPX -5.17% at 2398, NDX -4.00% at 7175, DJIA -6.28%.

The TPLEX continued its bear steepener amid a flight to cash seen across all major assets. The offer was most severe in APAC trade as US equity futures hit their limit down. The lift in equities after the US cash open also saw some support for the TPLEX, although ultimately proved short-lived. In the background participants are digesting the mass global fiscal stimulus packages being proposed, which will ramp-up supply. Furthermore, desks note the continued unwind of relative value and basis trades that have been blown up lately, in addition to wider profit-taking in the context of the pronounced drop in rates in the wake of the virus outbreak. By settlement, 2s/10s +7bps to around 63bps, levels not seen since 2018, with the 10-year yield +16bps to 1.16%; note that the 30-year yield reached close to 2% at one point. T-note futures (H0) settled 1 point 22 ticks lower at 134-12.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 18th March 2020: Scramble for dollar, crude collapsed, stocks crushed
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: COVID cases rise above 200k worldwide; US Phase 3 economic relief package touted at USD 1.3trln, with potential for more; Fed revives its PD Credit Facility; London and NYC move closer to lockdown; cable battered.
  • COMING UP: Data: Australian Employment, US Initial Jobless Claims. Events: SNB, RBA & SARB Monetary Policy Announcements. Speakers: RBA’s Governor Lowe. Supply: Spain, France, UK.

MARKET WRAP:

Policymaker pledges to pour stimulus into the economy may partly reassure, but has not engineered a revival in confidence. Asian equities could not rise despite the 6% rally on Wall Street on Tuesday, while US futures went limit down in overnight trade. US stocks found some support shortly after the open, although selling pressures continued later in the session, hitting the 7% limit down. Albeit fiscal measures seem poised to help where possible, the world increasingly begins to adjust to a lockdown, with growing expectations, and official suggestions, of hubs such as NYC and London on the cusp of such – measures that will undoubtedly cause severe near-term economic consequences and cause large downgrades to corporate stability. The greenback continues to retain the thrown (DX spiking above 100) as investors worldwide scramble to the door out of other asset classes – note cable was a noted sufferer, falling beneath 1.15 at one point! The oil benchmarks were shed heavily too, seeing WTI reach lows not seen since 2002, settling 24.4% lower, Brent was a relative “outperformer” at -13.4%. The TPLEX continued to bear steepen as the 30-year yield approaches closer to 2%, it fell below 1% just last week; meanwhile, the front-end remains more stable, catching some support from the Fed’s slew of new credit facilities – it revived another ’08 tool overnight, the Primary Dealer Credit Facility.

COVID-19:

US MEASURES: NEC Director Kudlow said the Phase 3 economic relief bill should bring USD 1.3trln worth of stimulus; prior reports had suggested USD 1.2trln, although details are murky on whether these figures are cumulative of the previous other two fiscal packages. Kudlow went further in his Fox interview to say that if it takes more than USD 1.3trln worth of stimulus, it will be done – even going as far as to say the government could take equity positions in companies! Meanwhile, President Trump announced the Defense Production Act (DPA) will be signed imminently. The measures will provide the President authority to require businesses to sign contracts or fulfill orders deemed necessary for national defense, in addition to a slew of other authoritative powers regarding resources and businesses. Trump also said FEMA has now been activated in all regions. Regarding medical care, he announced two Navy ships to be harnessed, with one hospital ship will be stationed on the West coast and one stationed on the East. Trump said he would hold another news conference either on Wednesday or Thursday regarding the FDA and COVID-19. Meanwhile, the Trump administration is proposing lending to air carriers (AAL, DAL, UAL, LUV, SAVE, JBLU) from the exchange stabilization fund following the new USD 50bln congressional appropriation, according to a Treasury memo. The administration proposal also seeks USD 150bln for loan guarantees to other distressed sectors, proposes disbursing USD 250bln to taxpayers starting April 6th and another USD 250bln in May; seeking USD 300bln for small business interruption loans.

MNUCHIN WARNING: Treasury Secretary Mnuchin has warned lawmakers that the US jobless rate could spike to 20% if no action was taken on a stimulus plan, according to a source, and could leave lasting damage. Mnuchin was making the case for a USD 1trln stimulus package, which would entail sending cheques to Americans within a fortnight. The chief of staff of VP Pence responded Wednesday, saying that no one is forecasting 20% unemployment right now. Although President Trump himself later said that the 20% figure was a “worst-case” scenario but added that the country is nowhere near it.

CANADA STIMULUS: Canada announced a CAD 27bln stimulus package for the economy, which amounts to around 3% of GDP. The Canadians will provide CAD 55bln to meet liquidity needs of businesses and households through tax referrals and will provide temporary wage subsidies for up to three months to allow businesses to keep workers on payroll. PM Trudeau said he was willing to do more with economic aid.

NY SHELTER IN PLACE: New York City Mayor De Blasio said that military assistance in the city is required, adding that he was almost at the point of recommending "shelter-in-place" to NY Governor Cuomo. On Tuesday, De Blasio pushed back on suggestions of a potentially imminent shelter in place order. Elsewhere, New York Governor Cuomo said there are now 2382 cases of the coronavirus in New York (prev. 1008).

LONDON LOCKDOWN REPORT: London is facing lockdown as the Government prepares emergency legislation to prevent the spread of coronavirus, according to The Telegraph, citing sources close to the Mayor's office. A shutdown could be announced in the coming days. At the daily UK government press conference, schools were instructed to close until further notice on Friday and PM Johnson, when asked whether London would be entering a lockdown, said the government wouldn’t hesitate to move further and faster when necessary, avoiding a direct answer, while also saying it was ruling nothing out.

EUROPEAN MEASURES: German Finance Ministry and Financial Regulator announced that the anti-counter cyclical capital buffer is to be cut to 0% from 0.25% starting April 1st, new regulations will give German banks a capital boost of over EUR 5bln; rate will stay at 0% until at least the end of 2020. Austria will provide up to EUR 38bln in its aid package; will provide another EUR 9bln in guarantees and warranties, EUR 10bln in tax deferrals, EUR 15bln in emergency aid. French regulators are set to allow their banks to tap their capital buffers which could free up to EUR 8bln; there were separate reports that EU regulators are reportedly weighing measures to give banks relief on bad loans, too.

CENTRAL BANKS:

FED PD CREDIT FACILITY: The Fed has brought back the Primary Dealer Credit Facility (PDCF), last used in the crisis, which is a secured lending facility allowing the use of various collateral types, namely, Treasuries and agency, IG corporate credit, international agency, commercial paper, municipal securities, mortgage-backed securities, asset-backed securities, and equity securities. Loans will be made available to primary dealers for a term of up to 90 days, at a rate equal to the primary credit rate in effect at the Discount Window. The PDCF will remain available to primary dealers for at least six months, or longer if conditions warrant.

NY FED OPERATIONS: No Term repo operations from the Desk on Wednesday, although it did carry out its two O/N operations, offering USD 500bln for each. However, the Fed’s persistent efforts to remove funding pressures, such as offering the second O/N operation each day for the rest of the week, in addition to both the new CPFF and PDCF has, for now, kept repo rates in check, thus Wednesday’s operations saw relatively small demand. Note that the Desk will offer USD 45bln in its 14-day Term operation on Thursday, in addition to its ongoing O/N ops.

ECB: The GC was reported in the latter session to be holding an emergency call on a COVID-19 response, according to sources, coming shortly after comments from the French Finance Minister calling on the ECB to take on more measures. Earlier on, ECB President Lagarde, as cited by FAZ, said she sees EZ GDP falling by 5% if the lockdown is extended. Following comments from ECB's Holzman in Der Standard (which appeared to suggest that monetary policy had reached its limits), the central bank said it stood ready to adjust all measures as appropriate and will continue to closely monitor the implications of the coronavirus. Holzmann himself also clarified his remarks, stating that the monetary toolbox was well equipped, and policy had not reached its limit. Meanwhile, ECB's VP de Guindos said the central bank stood ready to act with bold measures if necessary, adding that he expects the virus outbreak to have only a temporary impact on economies. ECB's Schnabel said the central bank is lowering its growth view, given that we are experiencing a major economic shock; she added that policymakers are closely monitoring credit markets, and are ready to act quickly if necessary. In terms of dollar liquidity, its 7-day operation saw take-up of USD 75.8bln, a huge rise compared to the circa USD 100mln levels that are usually seen.

ESCB: Sources said that the ESCB is intervening in the market via the Bank of Italy to ensure orderly market conditions, according to Reuters citing a Bank of Italy official. The interventions are flexible in timing and the markets that they cover, the report noted, and added, that intervention will continue as long as necessary.

BOE: New Governor Bailey fired a warning to markets, stating that investors who are making money by shorting assets against the interest of the UK economy should "just stop", though Bailey did not announce any short-selling bans, like other nations in Europe. Bailey said the MPC was watching GBP very carefully, taking note of the recent fall, and said it will consider the effects at the next week's policy meeting. The governor ruled out negative rates, arguing that it would likely hurt lending conditions and confidence, though added that everything was on the table that is reasonable within the policy toolset. Ahead, Bailey said that Covid-19 corporate financing facility was the first step, which the MPC aims to have operational next week, and this facility could be expanded; that facility can effectively buy new debt from companies, he said, but the total size of this is not possible to estimate. When asked about printing money for individuals says nothing is ruled out, but should not be interpreted as indicating they are about to undertake some measures. And he urged firms thinking of firing staff to first speak to the BoE and Treasury about what funding is available.

BOJ: Overnight, BOJ Governor Kuroda said Japanese financial institutions were not facing difficulties getting hold of dollars. He also noted that volatility facing Japan was less severe than in the US and in Europe, noting that ETF purchases had tamed volatility (estimated that the BOJ's losses on ETF holdings were probably between 2-3trln yen). Kuroda reiterating that the BOJ was prepared to ease further if required. While noting that the Bank can coordinate indirectly with fiscal authorities.

RBNZ: The Kiwi central bank said it would delay or slow most of its regulatory measures for an initial period of six months, and work closely with others to ensure the smooth operation of markets, and credit availability to households and businesses.

US ELECTION:

DEMOCRAT PRIMARIES: Former US VP Joe Biden was victorious in all three key Democrat Primaries on Tuesday night, with analysts now suggesting that his lead over Vermont Senator Bernard Sanders is almost insurmountable; the extreme-left Sanders is now facing calls to drop out of the race, which would allow Biden to concentrate on the November election amid the COVID fallout.

DATA:

CANADA INFLATION: Data came in largely in line with expectations (+0.4% M/M, +2.2% Y/Y), though analysts noted that the impact of COVID was not fully seen in the survey period, making it easy to look through the data. Inflation will slow in the months ahead, according to Canadian bank RBC, as the downward impact of the virus outbreak and the Saudi-Russia oil price spat on commodity prices, and what will ultimately be a dramatic fall in demand for a large swath of retail and services products flows through beginning more significantly in March. "Headline CPI could easily test the lows seen over the last five years (sub-1% in 2015)," the bank said, and "there could well be some additional downward pressure from discounts offered by coronavirus-affected businesses, though a weaker Canadian dollar (a byproduct of lower oil prices and risk aversion in financial markets) will add to the price of imported goods." In terms of policy implications, BOC says this means little in the near-term; "Lower inflation means the central bank won't feel conflicted about adding stimulus, but supporting the economy through this shock would have been its top priority anyway."

EQUITIES:

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -5.17% at 2398, NDX -4.00% at 7175, DJIA -6.28%.

SECTORS: Energy -14.24%, Financials -8.85%, Real Estate -7.45%, Industrials -7.1%, Materials -6.17%, Cons Disc -4.92%, Technology -4.59%, Utilities -4.59%, Health -3.38%, Cons Stpl -3.07%, Communication Svs -2.82%.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Another extremely volatile day for equities with the VIX making new highs above 85. Airlines saw heavy losses once again as the operators continue to reduce capacity and take cost-cutting measures. Some reports suggest airlines are looking to quickly cut workforces through an early retirement package or unpaid leave for up to one year with medical benefits in a move to reduce costs.  Delta Airlines (DAL), one of the worst-hit today, falling over 30% as it expects revenue to fall USD 2bln in March while cutting its system-wide capacity by 70% and reducing pay to its officers and directors by 50% and 25%, respectively. Boeing (BA) was also heavily weighed on after its appeal for USD 60bln in government aid, which includes access to public and private liquidity and loan guarantees for the aerospace manufacturing industry. Pershing Square’s Bill Ackman believes BA would not survive without a government bailout. Elsewhere, Casino operators and retailers continue to close down properties across the US, meanwhile, the hotel industry (H, HLT, MAR, HST) have asked the Trump administration for a USD 150bln bailout, according to WSJ - Bill Ackman believes there is a risk that HLT could go to zero. Detroit’s three largest automakers (GM, F, FCAU) agreed with the UAW to shut down US factories amid the coronavirus threat. Earnings from FedEx (FDX) saw revenue beat expectations, although EPS missed but its CEO stated it is ready to meet the increased demand for its international express export services due to the significant fall in intercontinental air capacity. General Mills (GIS) figures were more or less in line with expectations, although FY20 guidance was weak. Gilead (GILD) was mentioned positively at Piper, suggesting its COVID treatment, remdesivir, could receive FDA approval swiftly.

CRUDE:

SETTLEMENT: WTI (J0) SETTLED USD 6.58 LOWER (-24.4%) AT USD 20.37/BBL; BRENT (K0) SETTLED USD 3.85 LOWER (-13.4%) AT 24.88/BBL.

Both WTI and Brent sold off heavily on Wednesday trade with WTI trading around 20/bbl at the lows, levels not seen since 2002, and Brent at 25/bbl, WTI led the losses falling over 20% resulting in the Arb widening to over 5 bucks for the two products. Soured risk appetite was the key driver as the coronavirus continues to spread and spook markets as borders begin to shut, airlines continue to cut capacity and company operations begin to halt hurting the demand side even further. Also, Saudi Arabia and Russia appear to show no signs of backing down from its pricing war with Saudi’s Energy Minister directing Aramco to continue to supply crude at 12.3mln BPD over the coming months. Elsewhere, London oil giants Shell (RDS.A LN) and BP (BP LN) are reportedly chartering tankers to store fuel at sea; Shell to store 2mln bbls and BP to store jet fuel for up to 60 days – where participants are taking advantage of the steep contango the term structures are offering. Citi highlights the CapEx and production cuts from US shale companies “is only going to occur more gradually and over the intermediate-term, not soon enough to rebalance the market this year. Elsewhere, having little impact on pricing action, the latest DoE inventory data saw a smaller build than expected in headline crude while production increased to 13.1mln BPD (prev. 13mln BPD), while Tuesday evening’s private inventory data saw an unexpected draw in crude stocks – again, the sudden COVID-19 demand shock and OPEC pricing war remain at the forefront of driving oil prices.

BONDS

TREASURY SETTLEMENT: T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 1 POINT 22 TICKS LOWER AT 134-12.

The TPLEX continued its bear steepener amid a flight to cash seen across all major assets. The offer was most severe in APAC trade as US equity futures hit their limit down. The lift in equities after the US cash open also saw some support for the TPLEX, although ultimately proved short-lived. In the background participants are digesting the mass global fiscal stimulus packages being proposed, which will ramp-up supply. Furthermore, desks note the continued unwind of relative value and basis trades that have been blown up lately, in addition to wider profit-taking in the context of the pronounced drop in rates in the wake of the virus outbreak. By settlement, 2s/10s +7bps to around 63bps, levels not seen since 2018, with the 10-year yield +16bps to 1.16%; note that the 30-year yield reached close to 2% at one point.

BREXIT:

Under the radar, given COVID, however, negotiators have cancelled the round of talks that were due to take place today. Desks are beginning to talk about an extension to the current transition period, which the government will have to announce by the end of June. UK PM Johnson has previously been vehement that the UK will not be extending the transition, although COVID gives him the political cover to do so. In the UK government press conference on Wednesday, UK PM Johnson, when asked about the Brexit transition period, said we are getting on with it and the legislation is in place.

FOREX:

The dollar strength continues with DXY breaching 100 to the upside to highs of 101.75 as demand for cash continues to take precedence over other securities, particularly Gold and T-notes. The precious metal fell over 3% today and is back beneath 1500/oz, analysts at BMO Capital highlight the liquidity is “deeply compromised” thus expect to continue to see volatility and “mood-driven swings”. The haven outflows in government bonds have seen the curve bear steepen, likely aiding some of the support for the greenback. Another key driver for DXY strength is the heavy selling pressure in risk currencies, including GBP which saw lows at 1.14 before bouncing slightly back above 1.15. HSBC highlights GBP as “doing exactly what it says on the tin”, noting the recent weakness is because it is seen as a risk on currency and given the “risk on risk off” world, it is the reason for the underperformance. The analyst highlights NOK, AUD, GBP and NZD (in that order) as the most risk on currencies which is evident in today’s performance as all those listed have seen heavy weakness, even in that particular order. EUR fell victim to the stronger buck albeit less so than the risk on currencies mentioned above. The single currency ignored EZ inflation data which fell in-line with expectations, as data takes a back seat during the current market conditions.  JPY slightly weaker against the buck but firmer against the EUR, as is the story for CHF, where EURCHF remains well within 1.05-1.06. CAD was hit by the crushing fall in oil prices once again with USDCAD rising over 5 points from lows at 1.4166 to highs of 1.4651. The CAD 27bln (3% of GDP) stimulus package did little to support the Loonie. Meanwhile, the US and Canada agreed to partially close its borders but noted that trading would go ahead as normal. The decline in oil prices continues to weigh on the RUB & MXN, with USDRUB falling over 7% and trades above 80 and USDMXN briefly Crossed the 24-handle before paring slightly; Banxico did announce it would be auctioning another USD 2bln in FX hedges today. The soured risk appetite has weighed on EMFX in general, with ZAR and BRL both weaker despite continued FX intervention from the BCB. TRY also weaker but not to the same extent as its EMFX counterparts as the currency finds some solace in the lower oil prices.

Soured risk appetite was the key driver as the coronavirus continues to spread and spook markets as borders begin to shut, airlines continue to cut capacity and company operations begin to halt hurting the demand side even further. Also, Saudi Arabia and Russia appear to show no signs of backing down from its pricing war with Saudi’s Energy Minister directing Aramco to continue to supply crude at 12.3mln BPD over the coming months. Elsewhere, London oil giants Shell (RDS.A LN) and BP (BP LN) are reportedly chartering tankers to store fuel at sea; Shell to store 2mln bbls and BP to store jet fuel for up to 60 days – where participants are taking advantage of the steep contango the term structures are offering. Citi highlights the CapEx and production cuts from US shale companies “is only going to occur more gradually and over the intermediate-term, not soon enough to rebalance the market this year. Elsewhere, having little impact on pricing action, the latest DoE inventory data saw a smaller build than expected in headline crude while production increased to 13.1mln BPD (prev. 13mln BPD), while Tuesday evening’s private inventory data saw an unexpected draw in crude stocks – again, the sudden COVID-19 demand shock and OPEC pricing war remain at the forefront of driving oil prices.

analysis_details:
DPA Act Explained:

  • Authorizes the President to require businesses to sign contracts or fulfill orders deemed necessary for national defense. The second authorizes the President to establish mechanisms (such as regulations, orders or agencies) to allocate materials, services and facilities to promote national defense. The third section authorizes the President to control the civilian economy so that scarce and/or critical materials necessary to the national defense effort are available for defense needs.[3]
  • The Act also authorizes the President to requisition property, force industry to expand production and the supply of basic resources, impose wage and price controls, settle labor disputes, control consumer and real estate credit, establish contractual priorities, and allocate raw materials towards national defense.[3]
  • The President's authority to place contracts under the DPA is the part of the Act most often used by the Department of Defense (DOD) since the 1970s. Most of the other functions of the Act are administered by the Office of Strategic Industries and Economic Security (SIES) in the Bureau of Industry and Security in the Department of Commerce.[4]
  • The Defense Priorities and Allocations System institutes a rating system for contracts and purchase orders.[5] The highest priority is DX, which must be approved by the Secretary of Defense. The next level down is DO, and below that are unrated contracts

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar dominates whilst Sterling slips and commodity FX forfeit
content: Another rampant day for the USD amid further demand as traders and investors convert to cash and stay on the side-lines in light of the continuing market-wide sell-off. DXY has topped the key 100 mark (vs. intraday low of 99.150), having topped its previously-set YTD high of 99.915, with traders eyeing 102.20 (March 2017 high) and 103.80 (Jan 2nd 2017 high) as the next potential posts of resistance should the Buck continue to grind higher. Meanwhile, the Kiwi, Loonie, Aussie, and Sterling remained the weakest G10 links as renewed risk aversion continued to compound funding and liquidity squeezes, whilst Cable also eyes the prospect of a London-wide lockdown with sources flip-flopping on the timing but failing to explicitly deny such measures. AUD/USD and NZD/USD both lost further ground below 0.6000, with the former hitting a 17yr low of 0.5859 (vs. high 0.6029) and the latter an 11yr base of 0.5806 (vs. high 0.5968) as European players leave for the day. AUD/NZD meanwhile drifts closer to parity, with the pair overall flat for the session, having fluctuated in a 1.005-15 intraday band ahead of the RBA’s unscheduled monetary policy announcement at 0330GMT (Full Preview Available on the Research Suite). GBP/USD meanwhile plummeted below 1.2000 to an intraday base of 1.1757 at the time of writing, whilst EUR/GBP extended its rally beyond 0.9200 to an EU peak of 0.9272 vs. today’s 0.9068 low. EUR succumbed to the Dollar throughout the session, albeit to a lesser extent, having hardly budged to ECB headlines but more-so lockstep action with the DXY’s rise above the key psychological mark. Elsewhere, safe-haven JPY and CHF have displayed degrees of resilience against the USD strength – USD/JPY hesitantly crept higher throughout the session as the pair reclaimed 108.00 to the upside from a sub-107.00 low (106.75). For what it’s worth, technicians may be keeping an eye on the 200 DMA (108.23) and 100 DMA (108.90) for potential mild resistance, although market conditions could prove such levels to be futile. The Franc pivoted 0.9700 against the USD heading into the EU close having printed an intraday base at 0.9566, with the SNB policy decision tomorrow’s main event (Full Preview Available on the Research Suite). In terms of Scandi FX, NOK was pummelled amid further detrimental losses in the energy complex, EUR/NOK surpassed 12.00 and then some to end the EU session at highs of ~12.1240 (vs. low of 11.5000), some 4.5% higher on the day. SEK experienced losses alongside, but to a much lesser extent than its Norwegian counterpart given a lower oil revenue dependency. Nonetheless, EUR/SEK remained firmly north of 11.000 having printed a high of 11.1950 and a base of 10.8500. Finally, EM FX fell prey to the overall risk aversion and the reigning Dollar – USD/TRY eyed 6.5000 to the upside following yesterday’s recoil back to sub-6.4000 levels post-CBRT. The USD/ZAR topped the 17.000 mark whilst USD/RUB tested 80.000 to the upside (vs. intraday low of 74.9000) on energy price-action.

analysis_details: • Utilities, Industrials and Energy are the worst hit sectors, with Industrials being weighed on as airlines continue to get beaten up by the coronavirus while more operators continue to reduce capacity and take cost cutting measures. Boeing (BA) also weighing on the sector significantly and leading losses in the Dow Jones, trading around USD 100/shr amid it’s announcement that it is seeking a minimum of USD 60bln in aid from the government. Energy names continue to reduce CapEx as energy prices continue to fall amid the coronavirus pandemic and with no sign of ease from Russia or Saudi Arabia. The soured risk environment has seen Defensives, Consumer Staples and Health Care, as relative outperformers, albeit still down over 4%. Clorox (CLX) and Gilead (GILD) are among few companies trading in positive territory today given the former sells cleaning supplies, and the latter is aiming to develop a vaccine for the coronavirus, while it was also upgraded at DZ Bank. FedEx (FDX) also firmer after earnings which missed on EPS but beat on revenues, while its CEO stated it is ready to meet the increased demand for its international express export services due to the significant fall in intercontinental air capacity. Kroger (KR) and Walmart (WMT) also in the green following upgrades.

subject: Additional US Equity Stories: COP, AAPL, CMG, COP, ECL, KEYS, KR, SBUX
content:
• Apple (AAPL) unveiled its latest MacBook Air, valued at USD 999 which has faster performance the new “magic keyboard”, and twice as fast CPU performance.
  • Automakers (F, GM, FCAU) have reportedly come to an agreement with the UAW to slow production at its factories in the US and to limit the number of workers on the job at one time to help limit the spread of the coronavirus, according to CNBC.
  • Chipotle (CMG) and Uber Eats (UBER) announced a national delivery partnership where CMG food is now available on the Uber Eats app.
  • ConocoPhillips (COP) announced its 2020 operating capital expenditure plan will be reduced by USD 700mln, a 10% reduction from previously announced guidance. Reductions in production planned is expected to impact FY20 production guidance by roughly 20k barrels of oil equivalent per day. Its planned share repurchase programme will be reduced to a quarterly run rate of USD 250mln in Q2. The combined actions represent a 2.2bln cash use reduction in 2020.
  • Ecolab (ECL) confirms its Q1 20 guidance: Adj. EPS 1.05-1.13 (exp. 1.09)
  • Keysight Tech. (KEYS) announced it has temporarily closed many of its stores globally until the end of the month to help limit the spread of the coronavirus.
  • Kroger (KR) upgraded to Outperform from Market Perform at Telsey Advisory
  • Starbucks (SBUX) announced it is to repurchase up to 40mln shares, noting the programme shows its confidence and optimism about the long term growth opportunity for its business. It also announced 90% of its stores in China are open.
  • Tesla (TSLA) is reportedly facing a lawsuit from Sharp that alleges mobile communications equipment installed in TSLA models violates patents owned by Sharp.

subject: EU Trade Commissioner Hogan spoke with USTR Lighthizer at the start of the week before US hiked tariffs on EU aircrafts, Hogan underscored a strong view that both sides should focus on negotiating a settlement
Netherlands cases of the coronavirus stands at 2051, vs. around 1700 earlier in the week
Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 18th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) announced it appreciates the support from President Trump, noting it supports a minimum USD 60bln access to public and private liquidity, including loan guarantees for the aerospace manufacturing industry.
  • Of note for Airlines (DAL, AAL, LUV, UAL) (Industrials/Airlines), Airlines are seeking to quickly cut workforces through early retirement packages or unpaid leave.
  • FedEx (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) Q3 20 (USD): EPS 1.41 (exp. 1.43), Revenue 17.5bln (exp. 16.9bln).

18th March 2020

  • The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1300GMT/0900CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news
  • Of note for Airlines (DAL, AAL, LUV, UAL) (Industrials/Airlines), Airlines are seeking to quickly cut workforces through early retirement packages or unpaid leave for up to 1 year with medical benefits in a cost reduction move.
  • Of note for automakers (F, GM, FCAU, TSLA, TM), February EU passenger car registrations -7.4% to 957,052 units.
  • Of note for Casino operators (CZR, ERI, PENN, BYD, FLL) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure), Penn National Gaming (PENN) announced it is to temporarily suspend its operations at its Hollywood Casino at Charles Town Races. Further, Boyd Gaming (BYD) announced all of its properties in Nevada, Kansas, Iowa and Missouri are closing to the public temporarily. Eldorado Resorts (ERI) and Full House Resorts (FLL) are temporarily suspending operations at its casinos in Nevada, meanwhile, Caesars (CZR) is temporarily halting operations across North America.
  • Of note for Hotel Names (H, HLT, MAR) – The hotel industry has reportedly asked the US President Trump administration for a USD 150bln bailout, according to WSJ. With USD 100bln being used to retain its workers, while the remaining USD 50bln is service debt.
  • Of note for retailers, Target (TGT) (Consumer Discretionary/General Merchandise Stores) announced from today all of its stores will close by 21:00 local time to provide time for cleaning and restocking. Best Buy (BBY) is also reducing its opening hours. Gap (GPS) is temporarily closing its North American stores, Tilly’s (YLYS) is temporarily closing its stores.

Dow Jones

  • American Express Co (AXP) (Financials/Consumer Finance) had its PT lowered at Stephens to USD 100 from 144 (prev. close 86.58). Analyst Vincent Caintic previously lowered his EPS and revenue forecasts due to lower share buybacks as he now believes there will be no repurchases in H1 20. However, the analyst felt optimistic after an investor call and maintains his equal weight rating, stating it is tough to recommend buying while the US economy has not hit the bottom.
  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) unveiled its new iPad Pro, which is set to be available in stores as of next week.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) announced it appreciates the support from President Trump, noting it supports a minimum USD 60bln access to public and private liquidity, including loan guarantees for the aerospace manufacturing industry. Boeing (BA) previously told the US government it cannot meet its liquidity needs under the current market conditions.
  • Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) raised USD 8.5bln in new debt, although it had to pay a higher premium than usual due to the fall in oil prices.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) was upgraded to outperform from neutral at Credit Suisse, where the analyst believes it may grow market share due to the coronavirus causing a long-term structural change in consumer buying habits.

Nasdaq 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOGL), Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) and other tech companies are reportedly working with the US government to see if social distancing is working by using location data while exploring ways to stop the virus, according to Washington Post. Elsewhere, Google has reportedly been accused of not protecting its contract workers from the coronavirus, according to Business Insider citing a memo.
  • Baidu (BIDU) (Communication Services/interactive Media & Services) is to raise its salaries of staff amid the coronavirus pandemic, according to people familiar with the matter.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) was ordered to stop production at its Fremont, California factory, despite CEO Musk’s plan to keep it open.

S&P 500

  • CVS Health (CVS) (Health Care/Health Care Services) accidentally sent the wrong information to its staff about how to tackle the coronavirus, according to a company spokesperson cited by CNN.
  • Emerson Electric Company (EMR) (Industrials/Electrical Components & Equipment) authorised a new 60mln share repurchase programme over the next several years.
  • FedEx (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) Q3 20 (USD): EPS 1.41 (exp. 1.43), Revenue 17.5bln (exp. 16.9bln), suspended its FY20 forecast due to uncertainty surrounding the coronavirus, but it does expect capital intensity to fall in FY22. Operating Margin 2.8% (prev. 5.8%). CEO stated it is ready to meet the increased demand for its international express export services due to the significant fall in intercontinental air capacity, adding it remains well-positioned to help its customers as they work to manage the supply chains and inventories. 
  • General Mills (GIS) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) Q3 20 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.77 (exp. 0.76), Revenue 4.2bln (exp. 4.21bln), expects a step up in its organic sales growth in Q4. FY20 Adj. EPS 3.28-3.30 (exp. 3.36, prev. 3.22).
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) announced it is to suspend overtime at US plants to allow time for further cleaning to help prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
  • Halliburton Co. (HAL) (Energy/Oil & Gas Equipment & Services) announced it will furlough roughly 3500 staff in Houston for 60 days as shale producers cut spending amid falling oil prices.
  • Marathon Petroleum (MPC) (Energy/Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing) named Michael Hennigan as president and CEO effective immediately, succeeding current CEO Gary Heminger who is set to retire after 45 years, as previously announced. MPC is to also retain its midstream structure.
  • McKesson Corp. (MCK) (Health Care/Health Care Distributors) raised its FY20 adj. EPS view to (USD) 14.67-14.87 (exp. 14.76, prev. 14.60-14.80). Goldman Sachs also upgraded the Co stating it is “somewhat insulated” from coronavirus headwinds to see a significant impact to its figures.
  • United Continental Holdings (UAL) (Industrials/Airlines) announced a 60% reduction in its scheduling in April, including a 42% fall in US and Canada, and 85% decrease in international flights.

Other

  • Emergent Biosolutions (EBS) and Vaxart (VXRT) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced it has entered an agreement where EBS will utilise its molecule to market contract development and manufacturing services to develop VXRT’s potential oral vaccine for the coronavirus.
  • JetBlue (JBLU) (Industrials/Airlines) announced initial capacity reductions and pay cuts for VPS and above, voluntary time off programmes, adding it will be reducing its capacity in the upcoming months, with a reduction of at least 40% in April and May, while anticipating substantial cuts in June and July, while also announcing it is grounding some of its aircraft. JBLU also stated it may have to dip into its cash savings.  
  • MongoDB (MDB) (Information Technology/IT Services) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS -0.25 (exp. -0.28), Revenue 124mln (exp. 111mln); Q1 20 EPS view -0.25 to -0.22 (exp. -0.28), revenue view 119-121mln (exp. 116mln). FY21 Adj. EPS -1.40 to -1.23 (exp. -0.79), revenue view 510-530mln (exp. 530.2mln); FY21 guidance includes coronavirus impact. CTO and co-founder Horowitz announced he is to step down, but will become a technical adviser after leaving the full-time position.
  • NIO Inc. (NIO) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) CEO announced it delivered 8224 ES8 and ES6 vehicles in Q4 of 19, a 71.4% increase Q/Q, it delivered 20565 in 2019, an 81.2% increase Y/Y.
  • Qiagen (QGEN) (Health Care/Life Sciences Tools & Services) announced it has plans to increase production capacity of its RNA extraction kits that are used around the world to help detect nucleic acid in the coronavirus.
  • Tegna (TGNA) (Communication Services/Media) had an offer from Najafi Companies and Trinity Broadcasting network to take the co. private at USD 20/shr, which values TGNA at USD 4.4bln. Note, Apollo also made a USD 20/shr offer for the co. previously.

subject: BoE Governor Bailey says we are watching Sterling very carefully, takes note of the recent fall and will consider the effects of this at the next MPC
content:
• Negative rates in the UK would likely hurt lending conditions and confidence
  • Covid-19 corporate financing facility is the first step, which they aim to have operational as of next week and this could be expanded; such a facility can effectively buy new debt from companies but the total size of this is not possible to estimate
  • Firms thinking of firing staff should first speak to the BoE & Treasury about what funding is available
  • Investors who are making money by shorting against the interest of the UK economy should "just stop"
  • Everything is on the table that is reasonable within the policy tool set
  • When asked about printing money for individuals says nothing is ruled out, but should not be interpreted as indicating they are about to undertake some measures
analysis_details: • Next meeting is March 26th

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 18th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • US Equity futures have resided at limit-down throughout the European session
  • Debt complex has been heavily subdued while the DXY has printed fresh YTD highs
  • Fed established a primary dealer facility to support market function beginning March 20th which will last at least 6 months for 90-day loans
  • Former VP Biden was declared winner in the Florida, Illinois and Arizona Democrat primaries
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Building Permits and Housing Starts, Canadian CPI, DoEs, NZ GDP, Japanese CPI

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Mainland China reported 13 additional cases of coronavirus and 11 additional deaths on March 17th vs. Prev. 21 additional cases and 13 additional deaths on March 16th, to bring the total number of coronavirus cases in China to 80894 and death toll at 3237. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 93 more cases of new coronavirus for total of 8413 and the death toll rose by 3 to total of 84. (Yonhap)

Japanese PM Abe states that Japan will be putting together an ample economic package and will be conducting expert hearings on the package from tomorrow. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the virus will yield 20% jobless rate without policy action, while there were separate reports that the US coronavirus plan to combat coronavirus warned policy makers last week that pandemic will last for 18 months involving shortages. (Newswires/New York Times)

US President Trump tweets that money is coming for those out of work due to containment measures, adding that "The onslaught of the Chinese Virus is not your fault!". (Twitter)

Nevada ordered the shutdown of non-essential businesses including casinos for 30-days. (Newswires)

US and Canada will announce an agreement to partially close the border on Wednesday while permitting trade and commerce to continue. (The Globe and Mail)

Canada is to announce CAD 27bln economic and aid package on Wednesday to offset coronavirus impact, according to a government source. Furthermore, the package will boost unemployment insurance payments, child benefits and push back tax deadlines, although the source added that Canada is not yet ready to offer aid to airlines. (Newswires)

Germany's total coronavirus cases rose to 9257 vs. 6012 on Tuesday, according to Der Spiegel; RKI Institute sees an exponential growth of the virus in Germany. (Newswires)

German Finance Minister Scholz says they are thinking on how they can directly support some firms given the coronavirus crisis, according to Die Zeit; can help in the case of big companies such as airlines and cruise companies - not aiming to nationalise. (Newswires)

Italy could extend the current lockdown beyond April 3rd, according to La Stampa. (La Stampa)

Irish PM Varadkar said Ireland could see 15000 cases of coronavirus by end of the month and that at some point, we will tell the elderly and those with underlying illnesses to stay at home for a number of weeks. Furthermore, he added that there will be help from banks and government utilities for those who lost jobs, while damage to the economy will be significant and lasting with the bill enormous although noted it is possible to borrow billions of EURs on financial markets if needed. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets were indecisive as the region failed to sustain the rebound on Wall St from its worst sell-off since 1987, where sentiment was underpinned by efforts to address the coronavirus fallout including reports US plans stimulus of as much as USD 1.2tln consisting of a USD 300bln deferral in IRS payments and sending checks to citizens within 2 weeks, while the Fed also announced it will establish a commercial paper funding facility to support credit flow. ASX 200 (-6.4%) underperformed amid heavy losses in the tech and energy sectors, as well as a retreat in US equity futures after-hours which hit limit down, while Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) was initially positive following better than expected trade data despite Exports remaining at a contraction for the 15th consecutive month but the pared gains heading into the close. In terms of the notable stock movers, Fujifilm Holdings hit limit up after reports that China said the Co.’s influenza medicine was effective against coronavirus and are said to plan officially recommending the drug’s use for treatment, while SoftBank shares were at the other side of the spectrum on news it is backing away from part of the planned WeWork bailout. Hang Seng (-4.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.8%) also conformed to the indecision and ahead of key earnings from Hong Kong heavyweight Tencent with broad selling later triggered after US equity futures hit limit down. Finally, 10yr JGBs declined as they tracked the recent losses in T-noted, and although prices initially rebounded off their lows after finding support at 152.00 and with the BoJ in the market for nearly JPY 1.2tln of JGBs heavily concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities, this was short-lived and selling was then exacerbated on a break below the aforementioned support.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0328 vs. Exp. 7.0286 (Prev. 7.0094)

China’s Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng said they are very angry with US President Trump’s reference to ‘Chinese virus’. (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance (Feb) 1109.8B vs. Exp. 917.2B (Prev. -1312.6B, Rev. -1313.2B) Japanese Exports (Feb) Y/Y -1.0% vs. Exp. -4.3% (Prev. -2.6%) Japanese Imports (Feb) Y/Y -14.0% vs. Exp. -14.4% (Prev. -3.6%, Rev. -3.5%)

US

Fed established a primary dealer facility to support market function beginning March 20th which will last at least 6 months for 90-day loans and noted the interest rate will be at the discount window rate, while it will accept broad range of investment grade debt for collateral for loans to primary dealers. (Newswires) New York Fed is to offer USD 1trln in overnight repo operations for the remainder of the week (USD 500bln both in the morning and afternoon). (Newswires)

USD - Operations

-        ECB takes USD 75.8bln in its ECB 84-day USD operation

-        SNB allots USD 315mln in their 84-day USD repo operation, at a rate of 0.38%

-        BoE allot USD 7.245bln in their 84-day USD repo operation

Fed's George (Non-Voter, Hawk) says KC Fed continues to carry out key functions in this extraordinary time and we stand ready to lend through discount window, as well as address any regulatory or supervisory concerns. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (Non-Voter) says Fed actions are meant to show there will be maximum stimulus available now and when US gets on the other side; term auction facility among the next possible steps from the Fed which needs to consider and "be creative" in ways to aid SMEs. (Newswires)

Former VP Biden was declared winner in the Florida, Illinois and Arizona Democrat primaries. (Newswires)

UK/EU

European member states are reportedly divided over when and under what conditions the EUR 500bln ESM could be used to support the Euro Zone, according to diplomats. (FT)

German Finance Ministry and Financial Regulator announces that anti-counter cyclical capital buffer to cut to 0% from 0.25% starting April 1st, until at least year-end; new regulations will give German banks a capital boost of over EUR 5bln. (Newswires)

France and Belgium announced short-selling bans for a month each; while Italy is to implement a ban for 3-months. (Newswires)

ESCB is intervening, via the Bank of Italy, to ensure orderly conditions in the market, according to Bank of Italy sources; interventions are flexible in timing and markets, will continue for as long as is necessary. Interventions are aimed at clarifying if markets have any doubt regarding the decisions taken by the ECB GC. (Newswires)

ECB's Holzmann says the monetary toolbox is well equipped and monetary policy has not reached its limit. (Newswires) Note, these comments were a walk-back of his overnight remarks and we’re clarified by the ECB.

ECB's Schnabel says they are lowering their growth forecast, and we are experiencing a major economic shock; are closely monitoring credit markets for companies and governments are ready to act quickly if it is necessary. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Circuit Breakers available on Newsquawk feed

Further detrimental losses seen in the European equity space [-5.9%] as optimism surrounding yesterday’s US intervention faded in overnight trade as virus fears continue to materialise, with Western countries’ operations coming to halt amid lockdown procedures in an attempt to slow the spread. Meanwhile, US equity futures have been locked in limit down since late-APAC trade following yesterday’s fleeting reprieve. Italy’s FTSE MIB (-2.5%) cushions some losses after Italy implemented a carpet ban on short-selling Italian stocks for three months. France’s CAC (-5.5%) fails to derive much support from its one-month short-sell ban. European sectors are mostly in the red, albeit defensives fare slightly better than cyclicals. Telecom names outperform drastically as consumers confined work-from-homes and self-quarantines exercise broadband use- with BT (+3.8%), Telecom Italia (+5.0%), and Orange (+5.1%) all benefitting as such. Energy meanwhile lags in the region, in-fitting with price action in the complex. Individual story-driven movers prove to be futile at this stage, although MTU Aero Engines (-17.9%), Rolls-Royce (-13.6%) experiences extra downside from broker downgrades.

Boeing (BA) says it supports a minimum of USD 60bln in access to liquidity for the airline industry; additionally, House Speaker Pelosi spoke with airline CEOs in which they agreed large and immediate action was required to help the aviation sector. (Newswires)

FX                        

USD - Demand for the Dollar is becoming insatiable and the scramble is stretching well beyond the realms of the currency markets, as stocks, bonds and commodities are dumped in near fire sale fashion. As a result, the index has posted a marginal new 2020 peak at 99.917 and it almost seems inevitable or destined to cross the 100.000 barrier at some stage.

NZD/CAD/AUD/GBP - The weakest G10 links and worst performers vs the Greenback as the funding and liquidity squeeze is compounded by renewed risk aversion, with the Kiwi now down under 0.5900, Loonie approaching 1.4350 and Aussie below 0.5950. Meanwhile, Sterling only gleaned brief support from the UK Government’s whopping additional coronavirus economic support package as Cable relinquished more big figures on the way through the psychological 1.2000 level, while Eur/Gbp has extended its rally beyond 0.9100 to circa 0.9175.

JPY/CHF/EUR - All displaying a degree of resilience and resistance to the general attraction of the Buck, but not impervious by any means with the Yen straddling 107.00, Franc pivoting 0.9600 and still wary of the SNB either sticking to its quarterly policy review timetable or deciding to strike early. On that note, the Euro has already digested the ECB’s latest policy measures and is now taking on board what EZ Governments have (left) to offer while keeping tabs on 1.1000.

SCANDI/EM - No surprise that the Scandinavian Crowns have fallen prey to the latest bout of risk aversion, while the Nok is also watching the steeper slide in crude prices anxiously along with the Mxn and Rub that has Brent weakness and spread to WTI convergence to contend with. However, some retracement in Eur/Nok after the Norges Bank more than trebled daily FX purchase on behalf of the Government and also noted that more oil revenue will have to be converted for financing anti-COVID-19 initiatives. Elsewhere, the Rand appears vulnerable to a test of 17.0000 ahead of SA retail sales data and post-CPI that was firmer than forecast, but not sufficient to alter consensus for a 50 bp SARB rate cut tomorrow. Sticking with Central Bank easing, not much respite for the Try from cheaper crude costs after the full point intermeeting CBRT move on Tuesday.

Norges Bank are to increase currency sales on behalf of the Norwegian Government; from NOK 500mln to an amount equivalent to NOK 1.6bln. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

It would be premature if not profligate to suggest that the storm may have passed in debt markets, but futures have pared some losses after Bunds plunged to 168.37, Gilts hit a 130.99 Liffe low, 10 year T-notes slumped to 134-02+ and BTPs plummeted to 124.02. Consolidation and short covering doubtless played a part in the partial recovery given extreme oversold conditions, but like equities via circuit breakers and short selling bans/restrictions, the beleaguered Eurozone benchmarks also got a lifeline from official or orchestrated avenues in the form of ESCB intervention, according to sources. For the record, long end German issuance was absorbed adequately, but not welcomed with open arms given a huge concession, but spread divergence that was reaching blow-out proportions has abated somewhat.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures continue to slide with both contracts bleeding below the USD 30/bbl mark – with the former declining below its YTD low of ~USD 27.40 and ts 2016 low of USD 26.06/bbl. Brent meanwhile sees its 2016 low of USD 27.10/bbl, having tested levels close to USD 28/bbl in early EU trade. Underlying themes remain unchanged, with the demand picture further deteriorates as the number of countries implementing lockdowns stack up in a bid to slow down virus contagion. Elsewhere, the breakdown amongst OPEC members provides further pressure for the complex, with ING expecting weak oil prices for a prolonged time as Saudi and Russia do not show signs of backing away from production hikes. Elsewhere, spot gold meanders around the USD 1500/oz mark as it clocks in losses of over USD 30/oz amid the ongoing liquidating issues. Finally, copper prices see further detrimental losses amid demand concerns, a firmer Buck, traders on the sidelines and the overall sentiment, with the red metal approaching USD 2/lb vs. Monday’s USD 2.52/lb high.

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 13th Mar) -0.42mln vs. Exp. +3.3mln (Prev. +6.4mln). (Newswires)

Russia's Kremlin states that the current oil price is low, they would like this to be higher. (Newswires)

content: As anticipated, UK debt and STIR contracts have picked up where they left off yesterday (and prior to that) with the front end of the 3 month strip holding up well and markedly outperforming vs reds and beyond that are tracking an even more pronounced rebound in longer term rates on the back of growing financial commitments domestically and globally in the battle against nCoV. subject: Bunds: more fiscal fatigue and fleeting respite
content: The 10 year German benchmark has extended losses after an initial gap down and breach of the 171.00 level to the point that 170.00 has now caved with little in the way of meaningful resistance amidst the cascade of financial aid being pumped in to try and avert the worst of the COVID-19 social and economic contagion. Indeed, Bunds saw stops on a break of that round number and then technical ‘support’ circa 169.80 on the way to and through late January lows before settling down around 169.61. Ahead, Italian ip and trade alongside the pan Eurozone release, then final EZ CPI, but all stale and almost certain to be disregarded.

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
18th March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA 

Asian equity markets were indecisive as the region failed to sustain the rebound on Wall St from its worst sell-off since 1987, where sentiment was underpinned by efforts to address the coronavirus fallout including reports US plans stimulus of as much as USD 1.2tln consisting of a USD 300bln deferral in IRS payments and sending checks to citizens within 2 weeks, while the Fed also announced it will establish a commercial paper funding facility to support credit flow. ASX 200 (-6.4%) underperformed amid heavy losses in the tech and energy sectors, as well as a retreat in US equity futures after-hours in which S&P futures hit limit down, while Nikkei 225 (-1.9%) was initially positive following better than expected trade data despite Exports remaining at a contraction for the 15th consecutive month but the pared gains heading into the close. In terms of the notable stock movers, Fujifilm Holdings hit limit up after reports that China said the Co.’s influenza medicine was effective against coronavirus and are said to plan officially recommending the drug’s use for treatment, while SoftBank shares were at the other side of the spectrum on news it is backing away from part of the planned WeWork bailout. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) also conformed to the indecision amid ongoing coronavirus jitters and tentativeness ahead of key earnings from Hong Kong heavyweight Tencent with selling pressure later exacerbated after US equity futures hit limit down.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 18th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·       Asian equity markets were indecisive as the region failed to sustain the rebound on Wall St from its worst sell-off since 1987

·       UK Chancellor Sunak announced new measures including cash grants, tax holidays, mortgage moratoriums and lending facilities

·       Canada is to announce a CAD 27bln economic and aid package today to offset the coronavirus impact

·       DXY slightly pulled back overnight but held on to the majority of gains seen in the prior session where it surged above 99.00

·       Looking ahead, highlights include EZ CPI, US Building Permits and Housing Starts, Canadian CPI, DoEs, NZ GDP, Japanese CPI, supply from Germany

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Mainland China reported 13 additional cases of coronavirus and 11 additional deaths on March 17th vs. Prev. 21 additional cases and 13 additional deaths on March 16th, to bring the total number of coronavirus cases in China to 80894 and death toll at 3237. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 93 more cases of new coronavirus for total of 8413 and the death toll rose by 3 to total of 84. (Yonhap)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the virus will yield 20% jobless rate without policy action, while there were separate reports that the US coronavirus plan to combat coronavirus warned policy makers last week that pandemic will last for 18 months involving shortages. (Newswires/New York Times)

Nevada ordered the shutdown of non-essential businesses including casinos for 30-days. (Newswires)

US and Canada will announce an agreement to partially close the border on Wednesday while permitting trade and commerce to continue. (The Globe and Mail)

Canada is to announce CAD 27bln economic and aid package on Wednesday to offset coronavirus impact, according to a government source. Furthermore, the package will boost unemployment insurance payments, child benefits and push back tax deadlines, although the source added that Canada is not yet ready to offer aid to airlines. (Newswires)

EU leaders agreed to close borders to prevent virus spread in which borders will be shut for a 30-day period. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Sunak announced new measures including cash grants, tax holidays, mortgage moratoriums and lending facilities, with government interventions to be made in the economy on an "unimaginable" scale. The measures include GBP 330bln of guarantees for business and every single shop, pub and others in hospitality will pay no business rates for 12 months, while the UK is to support liquidity for larger firms and there will be a facility to support lending to SMEs. Furthermore, mortgage lenders will offer a 3-month payment holiday for those in need and the NHS will get whatever funding it needs, while further measures will be announced in the coming days. (Newswires) UK PM Johnson said although measures are extreme, we may have to go further and faster in the coming days and are doing all we can to increase NHS capacity, while he later stated we are keeping the situation regarding schools under continuous review. (Newswires)

Irish PM Varadkar said Ireland could see 15000 cases of coronavirus by end of the month and that at some point, we will tell the elderly and those with underlying illnesses to stay at home for a number of weeks. Furthermore, he added that there will be help from banks and government utilities for those who lost jobs, while damage to the economy will be significant and lasting with the bill enormous although noted it is possible to borrow billions of EURs on financial markets if needed. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets were indecisive as the region failed to sustain the rebound on Wall St from its worst sell-off since 1987, where sentiment was underpinned by efforts to address the coronavirus fallout including reports US plans stimulus of as much as USD 1.2tln consisting of a USD 300bln deferral in IRS payments and sending checks to citizens within 2 weeks, while the Fed also announced it will establish a commercial paper funding facility to support credit flow. ASX 200 (-6.4%) underperformed amid heavy losses in the tech and energy sectors, as well as a retreat in US equity futures after-hours which hit limit down, while Nikkei 225 (-1.9%) was initially positive following better than expected trade data despite Exports remaining at a contraction for the 15th consecutive month but the pared gains heading into the close. In terms of the notable stock movers, Fujifilm Holdings hit limit up after reports that China said the Co.’s influenza medicine was effective against coronavirus and are said to plan officially recommending the drug’s use for treatment, while SoftBank shares were at the other side of the spectrum on news it is backing away from part of the planned WeWork bailout. Hang Seng (-2.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) also conformed to the indecision and ahead of key earnings from Hong Kong heavyweight Tencent with broad selling later triggered after US equity futures hit limit down. Finally, 10yr JGBs declined as they tracked the recent losses in T-noted, and although prices initially rebounded off their lows after finding support at 152.00 and with the BoJ in the market for nearly JPY 1.2tln of JGBs heavily concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities, this was short-lived and selling was then exacerbated on a break below the aforementioned support.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0328 vs. Exp. 7.0286 (Prev. 7.0094)

US President Trump said he took exception to China suggesting that the US brought the virus into China and said it is accurate that the virus came from China. (Newswires) China Foreign Ministry said China is taking countermeasures against the restrictions placed on its media agencies in the US in which it moved to disallow US journalists from WSJ, NYT and The Washington Post from working in the country, while they were also comments from Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng that they are very angry of US President Trump’s reference to ‘Chinese virus’. (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance (Feb) 1109.8B vs. Exp. 917.2B (Prev. -1312.6B, Rev. -1313.2B) Japanese Exports (Feb) Y/Y -1.0% vs. Exp. -4.3% (Prev. -2.6%) Japanese Imports (Feb) Y/Y -14.0% vs. Exp. -14.4% (Prev. -3.6%, Rev. -3.5%)

UK/EU

Group of asset managers told BoE Governor Bailey that financial markets should close for two weeks, according to WSJ citing sources. The call was held with senior executives from asset managers including Vanguard Group, BlackRock Inc. (BLK), JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) and Bank of New York Mellon Corp (BK), in which the industry is said to have told Bailey that most mutual funds weren't seeing large outflows yet. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel has stated that she could consider joint debt issuance in order to help mitigate the impact from COVID-19; a move that could lead to a large overhaul of European finances. (Newswires)

European member states are reportedly divided over when and under what conditions the EUR 500bln ESM could be used to support the Euro Zone, according to diplomats. (FT)

Italy’s market regulator banned short-selling for 3-months in an attempt to curb volatility, while France and Belgium also announced short-selling bans for a month each. (Newswires)

FX

DXY slightly pulled back overnight but held on to the majority of the gains seen in the prior session where it surged above the 99.00 handle. Nonetheless, the greenback retreated off its best levels to provide some reprieve for its major counterparts including EUR/USD which briefly slipped below the 1.1000 level, while GBP/USD continued its rebound from support at 1.2000 to temporarily reclaim the 1.2100 handle after the government announced massive stimulus measures including GBP 330bln of guarantees for business. Elsewhere, USD/JPY retraced some of the prior day’s gains amid the mixed risk sentiment and antipodeans were kept rangebound due to their high-beta properties and after PBoC set the weakest reference rate YTD, although the AUD/NZD cross briefly reclaimed 1.0100 to the upside after rebounding from near-parity.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued overnight in which WTI crude futures extended on the prior day’s slump in prices amid reports that Saudi are to boost its oil exports to a record 10mln bpd. Furthermore, a surprise draw in the latest private inventory headline crude stockpiles did little to spur prices. Elsewhere, gold was flat for most the session but were later pressured as risk appetite deteriorated alongside the pressure across the commodity complex which saw copper shed over 3%.

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 13th Mar) -0.42mln vs. Exp. +3.3mln (Prev. +6.4mln). (Newswires)

CME raised RBOB gasoline futures margins by 20.3% to USD 7100/contract from USD 5900/contract. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Rockets were reportedly fired into the Green zone in Baghdad, Iraq, according to witnesses cited by LA Times reporter. (LA Times)

US

Fed established a primary dealer facility to support market function beginning March 20th which will last at least 6 months for 90-day loans and noted the interest rate will be at the discount window rate, while it will accept broad range of investment grade debt for collateral for loans to primary dealers. (Newswires) New York Fed is to offer USD 1trln in overnight repo operations for the remainder of the week (USD 500bln both in the morning and afternoon). (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Voter, Dove) said virus outbreak will quickly become an economic crisis for the US, while he added this could quickly become a recession and it could be a long crisis but noted the right reaction is to overreact to provide the best outcome. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (Non-Voter, Dove) said Fed actions are meant to show there will be maximum stimulus available now and when US gets on the other side, while he added that continuous turmoil in markets and across policy space convinced him last week for the need of Fed action. (Newswires)

Fed's George (Non-Voter, Hawk) says KC Fed continues to carry out key functions in this extraordinary time and we stand ready to lend through discount window, as well as address any regulatory or supervisory concerns

Former VP Biden was declared winner in the Florida, Illinois and Arizona Democrat primaries. (Newswires)

ASX 200 (-4.9%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.5%) are mixed with Australia pressured amid heavy losses in the tech and energy sectors, as well as a retreat in US equity futures after-hours, while the Japanese benchmark is positive following better than expected trade data despite Exports remaining at a contraction for the 15th consecutive month. In terms of the notable stock movers, Fujifilm Holdings hit limit up after reports that China said the Co.’s influenza medicine was effective against coronavirus and are said to plan officially recommending the drug’s use for treatment, while SoftBank shares were at the other side of the spectrum on news it is backing away from part of the planned WeWork bailout. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) also conform to the indecision amid ongoing coronavirus jitters and tentativeness ahead of key earnings from Hong Kong heavyweight Tencent.
